skill.name: tmux-processes
skill.description: Patterns for running long-lived processes in tmux. Use when starting dev servers, watchers, tilt, or any process expected to outlive the conversation.
skill.summary: Run and manage long-lived development processes in tmux sessions
skill.author: 0xBigBoss

security_audit.summary: Legitimate tmux process management documentation. Static findings are false positives triggered by shell syntax in documentation examples. All detected patterns (command substitution, backticks, /dev/null redirection) are safe documentation patterns for bash scripting.

content.value_statement: Development processes like dev servers and watchers need to run continuously beyond conversation context. This skill provides safe patterns for managing these processes in tmux sessions.
actual_capabilities: Create tmux sessions derived from project git root or current directory
Start long-lived processes in tmux windows with proper shell initialization
Check if processes are already running before starting new instances
Monitor process output and check for ready or error states
Restart processes by sending Ctrl+C and new commands
Kill specific project sessions without affecting other Claude Code instances
limitations: Requires tmux to be installed on the system
Does not provide direct stdout capture during conversation
Cannot manage processes outside of tmux sessions
Session names are derived from project path only

use_cases.title: Start development servers
use_cases.description: Keep dev servers running in tmux so they survive conversation context. Attach to check output or restart when needed.
use_cases.target_user: Developers working on long-lived web applications

use_cases.title: Run Tilt for Kubernetes development
use_cases.description: Start and manage Tilt sessions for local Kubernetes development workflows with proper session isolation.

use_cases.title: Monitor test watchers and log tailing
use_cases.description: Run test watchers and log tailing in separate tmux windows alongside development servers for comprehensive visibility.

prompt_templates.title: Start a dev server
prompt_templates.prompt: Start a dev server in tmux for this project. Use the project name for the session and run the appropriate dev command (npm run dev, rails s, etc.). Check if a session already exists first.
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to start a development server that persists beyond the current conversation

prompt_templates.title: Check if server is ready
prompt_templates.description: Poll the tmux session for ready indicators like 'listening', 'ready', or 'started' messages to confirm the server is fully initialized.
prompt_templates.prompt: Check if the dev server is ready by looking for 'listening' or 'ready' messages in the tmux session output. Poll for up to 30 seconds.

prompt_templates.title: Restart a stuck process
prompt_templates.description: Send Ctrl+C to stop the current process and send a new start command to the same tmux window.
prompt_templates.prompt: The dev server seems stuck. Send Ctrl+C to stop it, wait 1 second, then restart it with the dev command.

prompt_templates.title: Cleanup project sessions
prompt_templates.description: List all tmux sessions and kill only those matching the current project to avoid interfering with other Claude Code instances.
prompt_templates.prompt: List the tmux sessions for this project. Kill the project session when done to clean up resources.

output_examples.input: Start a dev server in tmux
output_examples.output:
Started dev server in tmux session: myapp
Use 'tmux attach -t myapp' to view output or 'tmux kill-session -t myapp' to stop

Killed tmux session: myapp
Session cleanup complete

best_practices: Always derive session names from git root or current directory to avoid conflicts
Use send-keys pattern instead of inline commands to ensure shell initialization runs properly
Check for existing sessions before starting to avoid duplicate processes
Never use tmux kill-server which affects all sessions on the system
anti_patterns: Running tmux kill-server or killing sessions not matching the current project
Using inline commands that bypass shell initialization and break PATH/direnv
Starting processes without checking if they are already running
Using hardcoded session names instead of deriving from project context

faq.question: Why use tmux instead of running processes directly?
faq.answer: Tmux sessions persist beyond conversation context. Processes started directly would terminate when the conversation ends. Tmux keeps dev servers, watchers, and Tilt running continuously.

faq.question: How do I see the output of a running process?
faq.answer: Use 'tmux attach -t session-name' to attach to the session and view output in real-time. Use 'tmux capture-pane' to programmatically check output for patterns.

faq.question: What happens if I start a process that is already running?
faq.answer: The idempotent patterns in this skill check for existing sessions first. If a session exists, it reports the process is already running instead of creating duplicates.

faq.question: Can this skill interfere with other Claude Code instances?
faq.answer: No. The skill derives session names from project git root or pwd. Each project gets its own session name. Following isolation rules prevents affecting other sessions.

faq.question: What processes should run in tmux?
faq.answer: Processes expected to outlive the conversation: dev servers, file watchers, test watchers, Tilt, database servers. One-shot builds and quick commands under 10 seconds do not need tmux.

faq.question: How do I stop a process gracefully?
faq.answer: Send Ctrl+C using 'tmux send-keys -t session:window C-c' or kill the specific window with 'tmux kill-window -t session:window' for immediate termination.
